input_text: QUESTION: I was in OH and was told that when proving "there exists," writing examples with specific numbers works. When proving "for all," writing examples with general numbers (ie. using variables) works. Just wanted to verify if this is okay? Was told to ask on Piazza for extra confirmation. Thanks!
output_text:
ANSWER:

This is something that we want you to think about further. What does it mean for something to "exist"? I'll give you a non-math example:

"Prove that there exists a human on earth named Ishaan." 

How would you prove this? Well, one way would be to just point to me, because I am a human on earth and my name is Ishaan.

But what if someone asked "Prove that for all humans, each human has a name"? Think about how you would go about proving that.

Now, think about how all of the above applies to number and variables. Keep in mind that variables can take on any value.

input_text: QUESTION: What is the difference between a proper subset and a subset? Is it just that for a proper subset to exist, the set in which the subset is included has to have some element that is not part of the subset? Also, are the notations different?
output_text:
ANSWER:

We say that $$A$$ "is a subset" of $$X$$, written $$A \subseteq X$$, if $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$a \in X$$.

We say that $$A$$ "is a proper subset" of $$X$$, written $$A \subset X$$, if $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$A \in X$$ and $$A \neq X$$.

In English, they are very similar, except proper subset insists that the Left Hand Side set is not the same as the Right Hand Side set.

input_text:
QUESTION:

While proving, when do we use contrapositives vs. contradictions?

It would be great if you could explain using an example. Thanks!
output_text:
ANSWER:

Both of these techniques are pretty similar and often both can be used on a question. I'll give you an example to show how both proof approaches could work.

Prove: for a positive integer $$x$$, if $$x$$ is even, then $$x + 2$$ is even. 

Contradiction: Suppose that $$x + 2$$ is not even. Then, $$x + 2$$ is odd, so we have $$x + 2 = 2k + 1 $$ for some $$k \in \mathbb Z$$. Then, $$x = 2k + 1 - 2 = 2k - 1 = 2(k-1) + 1$$. Since $$k-1 \in \mathbb Z$$, we have that $$x$$ is odd, which is a contradiction.

Contrapositive: Our contrapositive statement is: If $$x + 2$$ is odd, then $$x$$ is odd. Well, if $$x + 2$$ is odd, then $$x + 2 = 2k + 1$$ for some $$k \in \mathbb Z$$. Then, $$x = 2k + 1 - 2 = 2(k-1) + 1$$ and since $$k-1 \in \mathbb Z$$, then $$x$$ is odd and our contrapositive statement is proved.

You can see that in both proofs, we are doing very similar things. With contradiction, we are essentially adding a new assumption (in the above case, assuming that $$x+2$$ is odd), and our goal is to contradict one of our assumptions. In contrapositive, we are starting with a new hypothesis in a sense and working in the opposite direction. 

Contrapositive works when we have an "If... then..." statement (as these words imply implication). But contradiction may also work too.

input_text: QUESTION: Title.
output_text: ANSWER: "Without loss of generality" is commonly used when making a claim for some variables. For example, I would say something like "suppose $$a, b \in \mathbb Z$$, and without loss of generality, let  $$a < b$$". And then I would do whatever math needed. In the instance that $$b < a$$ I wouldn't have to do any math because the "symmetric" argument is covered with "Without Loss of Generality". That is to say, we can't just be throwing around WLOG whenever we want. We should only use it when the argument truly is symmetric.

input_text: QUESTION: Title!
output_text:
ANSWER:

Adding two outcomes works best when we perform "casework". That is, when solving a problem, we decide to break it down into smaller sub-problems (by perhaps casing on a constraint) and then adding all the values together to get a final value. Addition works when our casework is disjoint -- that is, no situation appears in multiple cases. You may also notice that adding (aka the addition rule) is essentially a corollary of PIE. In case this isn't clear, most problems that ask for a numeric answer can be considered as finding the cardinality of some set. Call this set $$A$$. Suppose we decompose the set $$A$$ into subsets $$A_1, A_2, A_3$$. Then, we want to find $$|A| = |A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3|$$.

using PIE, we have $$|A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3| = |A_1| + |A_2| + |A_3| - |A_1 \cap A_2|  - |A_1 \cap A_3| - |A_2 \cap A_3| + |A_1 \cap A_2 \cap A_3|$$.

Admittedly, this does not really look like the addition rule, but more often than not, we define $$A_1, A_2, A_3$$ in such a way that they are disjoint. That is, $$A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset$$. With this, a lot of terms in the PIE are equal to 0 and we are left with $$|A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3| = |A_1| + |A_2| + |A_3|$$.

TL;DR: If we decompose our problem into sub-problems that are disjoint, then we typically use the addition rule.

As for multiplication rule, this is often used for a multi-step procedure. That is, instead of decomposing a problem into separate smaller problems that must be solved "in whole", we instead decompose a problem into a step-by-step procedure.

The difference now is that we are looking at "all cases" to be considered and breaking down a procedure whereas for addition, we were looking at "some cases" at a time.

When you have a procedure, you can consider the amount of ways to perform each step. If the amount of ways to perform each step is constant regardless of how the prior steps were performed, then you can use the multiplication rule to find the total amount of ways the procedure can be carried out.

input_text: Say that I have 8 red balls and 8 blue balls. input_text: QUESTION: Does the presence of more than 1 base case mean strong induction?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Not necessarily. You can still do multiple base cases and do ordinary induction (where the base cases are just extra insurance).

In another direction, when doing strong induction, you will almost always have more than 1 base case.

input_text: QUESTION: Does the hint in #1 mean we can assume that every coefficient is unique (i.e., n!/r! = n!/(n-r)! would not apply?). If not, can someone clarify? Thanks!
output_text:
ANSWER:

The hint means that the value of $$\binom{n}{m}$$ will be different from $$\binom{n}{l}$$ so long as two conditions hold:

1) $$l \neq m$$ and $$l \neq n-m$$

2) $$1 \leq l \leq n$$

What you choose to take away from this hint is up to you

input_text: QUESTION: When we’re using induction, if while proving the k+1th case and the k+2th case is involved in the proof, do we need to use strong induction? Or is it only when the k-1th case is involved in the proof?
output_text:
ANSWER:

I think it is extremely rare to see the $$k+2$$ case, and even more specifically, anything greater than the $$k+1$$ case in the induction step. And if you do see this, we often do some sort of reduction to get it into a value that is $$\leq k$$, because then it is easier to apply the induction hypothesis (since the IH is generally assumed for values up to and including $$k$$).

However, if you see that the induction step would be easily solved by "borrowing" results from values less than $$k$$, then strong induction may be the way to go.

input_text: QUESTION: In lecture 5t, the last induction proof, why do they not do a proof for both directs for the iff statement? Is this logic applicable for all questions with biconditional statements?
output_text:
ANSWER:

That induction proof is proving both directions at the same time.

The forwards direction reads "If the first player has a winning strategy, then $$n \neq 4k + 1$$". We use the contrapositive (which is logically equivalent) to rewrite this as "If $$n = 4k + 1$$ then the first player loses". Note that this statement appears in our definition of $$P(n)$$.

The backwards direction is "if $$n \neq 4k + 1$$ then the first player has a winning strategy", and this is also encapsulated in the definition of $$P(n)$$.

In the induction step, we show both of these at the same time.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Do we need to represent each element of $$\Omega$$ as some tuple or ordered pair as show in lecture 5H?

For example, in problem 3, are we allowed to say that "The sample space is the set of ways for Ria to distribute the 9 cookies to the 4 customers", or do we need to say something like "Each outcome in $$\Omega$$ can be represented as a 4-tuple...."?
output_text:
ANSWER:

We have previously been quite lenient in how you define $$\Omega$$ in the past. However, if you rely on some sort of implicit structure of the outcomes within your solution, then it is usually define such a structure when defining $$\Omega$$.

For example, if you define $$\Omega$$ to be the "set of ways for Ria to distribute the 9 cookies to the 4 customers" and later in the solution you write something like "looking at the second position of the outcome, blah blah blah", then it's a bit stylistically unpleasant because we don't really know what a "position" is. Since the structure of an outcome in $$\Omega$$ wasn't well defined, we could have $$\Omega$$ be a set of tuples, a set of sequences, or even a set of sets (in this case, the word "position" wouldn't make much sense since sets are unordered).

My advice is to give structure to your outcomes regardless if you choose to use said structure or not.

input_text: QUESTION: I know that in the lecture notes, this was proved using contradiction. Could we prove this using the contrapositive, and if we can how would the proof look?
output_text:
ANSWER:

The contrapositive statement is: If $$n$$ is even, then $$3n + 2$$ is even.

If $$n$$ is even, then $$n = 2k$$ for some $$k \in \mathbb Z$$.

Then, $$3n + 2 = 3(2k) + 2 = 6k + 2 = 2(3k + 1)$$.

We know that $$3k + 1 \in \mathbb Z$$ since $$k \in \mathbb Z$$, so $$3n + 2$$ is also even. qed

input_text: QUESTION: In 7T  lecture notes, it says that "G − {e} has n vertices and n − 2 edges. We know that such a graph has at least 2 connected components and hence is disconnected." What is the justification for this?

ANSWER:

In lecture 6T you proved the following:

Every graph with n vertices and m edges has at least n − m connected components

So we're just using the above to justify it.

input_text: QUESTION: For the question that asks to find 8-letter strings with different numbers of vowels, for the portion of the question where we want to count all 8-letter strings with distinct letters that have 3, 4, or 5 vowels, why does step 2 have P(5, i) ways of doing it instead of $$\binom{5}{i}$$ ways? Are you not choosing i of the 5 vowels to use in the spots you've chosen in step 1?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Well almost. You can think of doing $$\binom{5}{i}$$ as choosing $$i$$ of the 5 vowels to use. But you still need to assign the vowels to the $$i$$ spots. So the first vowel spot would have $$i$$ options, the second vowel spot would have $$i-1$$ options, and so on until the $$i$$th vowel spot has $$1$$ option.

So in total, the amount of ways to assign the vowels is $$\binom{5}{i} \cdot i!$$, but this is just equal to $$P(5, i)$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

What is the number of non-decreasing sequences of length 10 whose terms are
taken from 1 through 25? 

This was a question from lecture 3H, for which I originally assumed that there can only be 1 of each number (we can only use the number 2 once in our list, if we decide to use it). In the solution, however, it seems like we assumed that we can use the same number twice. How do we know just from the wording of the problem that we can use a number twice? Do we assume that we can use a number twice unless it explicitly tells us each number can only be used once? 

Also, for this question, how do we know whether or not each number 2 that we use in our list is distinct or not? 

Thank you!
output_text:
ANSWER:

In this question, "non-decreasing" indicates that the sequence is never decreasing, but it could stay the same. So for example: 1, 2, 3, 4 is non-decreasing because it never decreases, but so is 1, 2, 2, 4. So repetitions would be allowed. For the sake of the exam, we'll make it clear what we are looking for. If not, just ask.

For the last question, I don't think it really matters. But the number 2 is indistinguishable from the number 2.

Screen_Shot_2023-10-13_at_6.57.17_PM.png

Each inequality $$(\leq, =, <)$$ is in relation to the step immediately prior, not in relation to $$\sum_{j=0}^k d_j \cdot 10^j$$.

input_text: QUESTION: In the PIE solution of this question, why are we choosing 10 from 12, 11, and 10?
output_text:
ANSWER: I’ll give you the argument for $$\binom{11}{2}$$ and the other cases follow similarly.

Consider the event $$X_i \cap X_j$$. This occurs when exactly two of the variables are equal to zero, so the equation simplifies to $$x_k + x_l = 10$$

We now treat this as sticks and crosses where the variables are distinct containers (so the plus sign is the stick) and the units of 10 are the crosses.

So by formula, $$\binom{11}{10}$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

how come 4b is not accounting for order (12 choose 2), but then 4d is accounting for order (13*12). Shouldn't 4d be (13 choose 2) for which two different values to choose from?
output_text:
ANSWER:

4d isn't really accounting for order. We can rewrite 4d with a more thorough procedure.

Step 1) Choose which value will form the three-of-a-kind

Step 2) Choose which three suits of the above value to have.

Step 3) Choose which value will form the pair.

Step 4) Choose which two suits of the above value to have.

Step 1 can be performed in $$\binom{13}{1}$$ ways, step 2 in $$\binom{4}{3}$$, step 3 in $$\binom{13-1}{1}$$, and step 4 in $$\binom{4}{2}$$. Then just use MR and you get the same answer presented

input_text: QUESTION: When finding the number of pairings why do we have to divide by 50! ? I thought that by just simplifying combinations (100 choose 2 times 98 choose 2 times 96 choose 2 and so on), we would get 100!/2^50. How would this overcount, I thought that order did not matter for combinations?
output_text:
ANSWER:

The order within the pair doesn't matter, but you should also consider the order of how you select the pairs. For example, if you do the $$\binom{100}{2}$$ followed by $$\binom{98}{2}$$ and so on approach, then consider the following scenario:

In the first step, the first two people we chose to form a group may be person $$A$$ and person $$B$$. And in step 2, when we are choosing 2 from the remaining 98 to form a pair, we may choose person $$C$$ and person $$D$$.

But currently, this would be different than in step 1 choosing people $$C$$ and $$D$$ and in step 2 choosing $$A$$ and $$B$$. 

Since we want the above two to be considered the same (i.e. the ordering of the pairs themselves don't matter), we have to divide by $$50!$$

$$\geq 2a + 3 = 2(a+1) + 1$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

I don't understand the latter part of the explanation. Could someone give a more detailed explanation?

"Clearly, this sequence is also a strictly increasing sequence. The numbers a1, a2, . . . , a77, a1+ 21, a2+21, . . . , a77+21 (154 in all) belong to the set {1, 2, . . . , 153}. By the pigeonhole principle there must be two numbers out of the 154 numbers that must be the same. Since no two numbers in a1, a2, . . . , a77 are equal and no two numbers in a1 + 21, a2 + 21, . . . , a77 + 21 are equal there must exist i and j such that ai = aj+21. Hence during the days j+1, j+2, . . . , i, exactly 21 games must have been played."
output_text:
ANSWER:

By PHP, we must have that two of $$a_1, a_2, ..., a_{77}, a_1 + 21, a_2 + 21, ..., a_{77} + 21$$ are equal. Since $$a_1 < a_2 < ... < a_{77}$$ it follows that $$a_1 eq a_2 eq ... eq a_{77}$$ and similarly, $$a_i + 21 < a_2 + 21 < ... < a_{77} + 21$$ so $$a_1 + 21 eq a_2 + 21 eq .. eq a_{77} + 21$$.

Thus, if $$A = \{a_1, a_2, ..., a_{77}\}$$ and $$B = \{a_1 + 21, a_2 + 21, ..., a_{77} + 21\}$$, from the pigeonhole argument, the two values that are the same MUST come from different sets. That is, $$\exists a_i \in A$$ and $$\exists a_j + 21 \in B$$ such that $$a_i = a_j + 21$$. The rest follows from this.

input_text:
QUESTION:

For one of the questions in Lecture 6T, we use induction on m edges to figure out the number of connected components and prove the claim.

My question is how do we know what to induct on for these questions? It isn't very intuitive for me.
output_text:
ANSWER:

What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.

For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)

What's nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don't have to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.

In the case of the lecture notes problem, I would be tipped to doing induction on edges because we are just looking at an arbitrary graph and don't know much about its structure. Had we chosen to induct on vertices and remove a vertex in the Induction step, we'd have to worry about its connectivity to all other vertices as well as how many edges we removed (especially since the claim depends on the number of edges).

By inducting on edges, we have much less to be concerned about. Often, trial-and-error is the best way of figuring out what to induct on.

QUESTION:

I understand why the explanation in the solutions is correct, but how is the following procedure overcounting?

Step 1. Choose 3 books: $$5 \choose 3$$ ways

- Step 3: Choose Anne and Mary

Procedure 2:

- Step 1: Choose books A, D, E

- Step 2: Give Anne book A, Mary book E, and Dan book D.

input_text:
QUESTION:

This is an IFF proposition, why don't we prove both sides?
output_text:
ANSWER:

That induction proof is proving both directions at the same time.

The forwards direction reads "If the first player has a winning strategy, then $$n \neq 4k + 1$$". We use the contrapositive (which is logically equivalent) to rewrite this as "If $$n = 4k + 1$$ then the first player loses". Note that this statement appears in our definition of $$P(n)$$.

The backwards direction is "if $$n \neq 4k + 1$$ then the first player has a winning strategy", and this is also encapsulated in the definition of $$P(n)$$.

In the induction step, we show both of these at the same time.

output_text:
ANSWER:

The induction hypothesis is assuming that the first player has a winning strategy if $$n \neq 4k + 1$$ AND if $$n \neq 4k + 1$$ then the first player has a winning strategy.

We can use the contrapositive on the first part of the IH to assume that if $$n = 4k + 1$$ then the first player does not have a winning strategy AND if $$n \neq 4k + 1$$ then the first player does have a winning strategy.

In case 1, we utilize the first part of the IH and in case 2 we utilize the second part.

input_text:
QUESTION: How do you write the contrapositive of a biconditional statement? For example, we solved the following problem from Recitation 2 using contrapositive:

Let m and n be two integers. Prove that mn + m is odd if and only if m is odd and n is even.
output_text:
ANSWER:

Remember that a biconditional is the conjunction of two implications. That is, $$p \iff q \equiv p \implies q \land q \implies p$$.

When proving a biconditional, we have to prove both directions. That is, we show that both $$p \implies q$$ AND $$q \implies p$$ holds.

To prove $$p \implies q$$, for example, you could choose to do it directly, or you could do it by contrapositive if you wish. That is, you could prove $$\lnot q \implies \lnot p$$.

Contrapositive only applies for an implication.

input_text:
QUESTION: How do we know z < r < y?

Additionally, was there any method to coming up with what r is?
output_text:
ANSWER:

If $$r = \frac{z + y}{2}$$ and $$z < y $$ then $$r > \frac{z + z}{2} = z$$. 

Similarly, $$r = \frac{z+y}{2} < \frac{y+y}{2} = y$$. So that's how we conclude $$z < r < y$$.

The logic for coming up with $$r$$ is that we wanted to yield a contradiction, and given that we defined $$z$$ to be the largest rational number in the interval, we were aiming to find something larger than $$z$$ that still falls within the interval. So the natural choices is the average between $$z$$ and the upper bound.

input_text: QUESTION: In general, how do you know when to use stars and bars vs when to use the equation for the permutations of a multiset?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Stars and bars is used to distribute indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers.

Permutations of a multiset is used to count the amount of ways to "arrange" or permute a grouping of items where repetitions are allowed (that is, there isn't much of a notion of "distribution").

input_text:
QUESTION:

For Q7, I provided an alternate solution to using strong induction to prove that any string of length n could be written in the form x = y \cdot z. For the induction hypothesis, I wrote that "Assume the claim holds true for 0 is less than or equal to j is less than or equal to k" for some integer k greater than or equal to 0 and all integers j in the range. That is, a string of length j can be written in the form x = y \cdot z". For the induction step, I partitioned the string of length k+1 into two nonempty binary strings of length a and b. Since 0 is less than or equal to a, b is less than or equal to k, the induction hypothesis could be used to say that both strings could be written as concatenation. Since in both strings, the number of 0's in y is equal to the number of 1's in z, a string of length k+1 can be written as concatenation such that the number of 0's in y is equal to the number of 1's in z (by way of adding the values). Thus, the induction step is proven.

I was wondering if this solution works for the proof.
output_text: ANSWER: I don't think this is quite right. Because if you split $$x = y \cdot z$$ and then apply the IH on $$y$$ and $$z$$ then you have $$x = (p_1 \cdot q_1) \cdot (p_2 \cdot q_2)$$ where the number of 0s in $$p_i$$ is equal to the number of $$1$$s in $$q_i$$. But how does this help solve the original claim? We cannot "combine" $$p_1$$ and $$p_2$$ because they are non-contiguous.

input_text: QUESTION: The solution uses PIE, but why would the answer C(8,3)* 3! * 3^5 not work? (Choosing 3 flyers to give to the freshmen at first, arranging them, and then choosing out of 3 options for each of the 5 remaining flyers)
output_text:
ANSWER:

Suppose you did have the following procedure:

Step 1) Choose 3 of the 8 flyers

Step 2) arrange the flyers

Step 3) Assign each of the remaining flyers.

Then consider the following two ways of following the procedure:

Procedure 1:

Step 1) Choose flyers 1, 2, 3.

Step 2) Permute them, and say the permutation is 1, 2, 3. (i.e. person A gets flyer 1, person B gets flyer 2, person C gets flyer 3).

Step 3) Suppose we give flyers 4 through 8 to person A.

At the end of the procedure, person A has flyers 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, person B has flyer 2 and person C has flyer 3.

Procedure 2:

Step 1) Choose flyers 2, 3, 4.

Step 2) Permute them, and say the permutation is 4, 2, 3 (i.e. person A gets flyer 4, person B gets flyer 2, person C gets flyer 3).

Step 3) Suppose give the remaining flyers all to person A.

At the end of the procedure, person A has flyers 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, person B has flyer 2 and person C has flyer 3.

Thus, we have ended with the same state by following the procedure in two different ways, so the procedure overcounts :(

input_text: QUESTION: how exactly do we define a cyclic tree? ie what exactly constitutes as a cycle? could we use something along the lines of "if a node can reach another node using more than 1 path"?
output_text:
ANSWER:

trees, by definition, do not have cycles, so there is no such thing as a cyclic tree. 

A cycle is defined as a closed path -- a sequence of vertices connected by edges such that all vertices are distinct except for the first and the last. 

For your last question, you should think about this on your own!

input_text: QUESTION: Is the question saying that every edge that belongs to T does not belong to T’? Or for such an edge if it exists, prove the claim?
output_text:
ANSWER:

No, you are told that $$T$$ and $$T'$$ are distinct, but this does not mean that $$E \cap E' = \emptyset$$. 

You need to show that for any and every edge that is found in $$E \setminus E'$$, that we can find some other edge in $$E' \setminus E$$ that abides by the claim.

In other words, for every edge found in $$T$$ that is not found in $$T'$$, we can find some edge in $$T'$$ that is not in $$T$$ such that the claim holds.

cheers

input_text: QUESTION: Hello, if there are only 2 random variables are pairwise and mutual independence the same? Thanks.
output_text: ANSWER: Yes. Mutual independence ensures that for every subset of random variables, the probability of their intersection equals the product of their individual probabilities. When the amount of random variables is 2, the only "subset" that is interesting is the subset containing the two rvs. This is equivalent to pairwise independence.

input_text: QUESTION: For the birthday paradox question, why is the answer for the probability of B = 1 − P(n, k) / n^k? I don't understand why we are permuting over k?
output_text:
ANSWER:

the numerator is counting the number of ways we could have $$k$$ people with different birthdays. consider the following procedure:

step 1: assign a birthday for first person (n ways)

step 2: assign birthday for second person (n-1 ways)

...

step k: assign birthday for kth person (n-k+1 ways)

By mr, you'll end up getting P(n, k)

input_text: QUESTION: I'm a little confused about how we got the numbers for Pr[A] and Pr[A union B]. Can someone help clarify these? Thank you!
output_text:
ANSWER:

For Pr[A], a simple explanation is to just consider the first card in your hand that has value V. From the remaining 51 cards, only 3 of them have value V, so the probability that the second card matches the value is 3/51.

$$A \cap B$$ describes the event when the first card is an Ace and the first two cards have the same value. That is, both the first and second card must be Aces. A deck of cards has 4 distinct Aces, so there are $$\binom{4}{2}$$ ways to have 2 aces in the first two cards. the denominator counts the total number of first two cards we could have

input_text: QUESTION: When do you use Pr[A] x Pr[B] versus Pr[A] x Pr[B|A] when expanding the numerator of P[A ∩ B] when solving a conditional probability problem?
output_text: ANSWER: $$Pr[A\cap B] = Pr[A] \times Pr[B|A]$$ by definition. $$Pr[A\cap B] = Pr[A] \times Pr[B]$$ if A and B are independent.

input_text:
QUESTION:

I believe we’ve defined if the sum of two numbers are even, then the numbers themselves are both even/odd. Similarly, the contrapositive is true.

Do we have to prove (albeit it being simple) the converse for any proof going forward? If the numbers are both odd/even, then the sum is even? We haven’t explicitly proved this in class.

It would make it simple to say that if we add/subtract an edge to an odd degree vertex, then the resulting new degree is even.

Thanks in advance!
output_text:
ANSWER:

you can assume basically everything involving addition/subtraction/multiplication of integers. That is, feel free to assume the following:

  • odd + odd = even
  • odd + even = odd
  • even + even = even
  • odd - odd = even
  • odd - even = odd
  • even - even = even
  • odd * odd = odd
  • odd * even = even
  • even * even = even

input_text:
QUESTION:

Hello, I have an alternate solution for number 3 on HW 10T and I wanted to check if it works. 

Essentially, We know that the expected value of X equals summation of i Pr[X=i] where i goes from 1 through 6. I first calculated the probability that X=i as follows: 

The sample space is all possible combinations of dice rolls that we can have, which has a cardinality of 6^4. 

The event is the number of ways that i can be the largest value. 

Essentially, there are 4 cases here whose probability we can add by TPT: Case 1 is that there is 1 die with value i. Case 2 is that there are 2 die with value i. Case 3 is that there are 3 die with value i. Case 4 is that all 4 die have value i. 

Case 1: The number of ways to have 4 dice rolls result in the largest number being i with exactly 1 die that has value i is (4 choose 1)*(i-1)^3, since we choose 1 of the 4 die to have value i, and then each of the other 3 dice have i-1 options for numbers because we need i to be the largest. 

Case 2: Similarly, number of ways to have 4 dice rolls result in the largest number being i with exactly 2 dice with value is (4 choose 2) * (i-1)^2. 

Case 3: exactly 3 dice with value i -> (4 choose 3)(i-1)

Case 4: exactly 4 dice with value i -> 1 

Then, the total probability of some roll of the 4 dice having a max value of i is ((4 choose 1)*(i-1)^3 + (4 choose 2) * (i-1)^2 + (4 choose 3)(i-1) + 1) / 6^4= (4(i-1)^3 + 6(i-1)^2 + 4(i-1) + 1)/ 6^4

We can then put this in the summation from i equals 1 to 6. 

Could you please let me know if this works? Thanks.
output_text: ANSWER: yep this seems fine to me

input_text: QUESTION: I was reviewing Lecture 12T, and I was wondering why the "less than or equal to" and "less than" symbols demonstrate antisymmetric relations.
output_text:
ANSWER:

It is true that $$\leq$$ is an antisymmetric relation. This is because $$\forall a, b \in \mathbb Z$$ if we have $$a \leq b$$ and $$b \leq a$$ (which is the precondition for an antisymmetric relation), then it must be the case that $$a = b$$.

When it comes to $$<$$, you'll note that it is not possible to have $$a < b$$ AND $$b < a$$ for elements $$a, b$$, so the precondition holds vacuously

input_text: QUESTION: Could someone please explain the above. I understand all the other relations except for these? Thank you!
output_text:
ANSWER:

For R4 being anti-symmetric, see @1391.

R5 is antisymmetric because suppose we have $$a \mid b$$ and $$b \mid a$$ for $$a, b \in \mathbb Z^+$$. Then, since $$a \mid b$$, we have $$b = k \cdot a$$ for some integer $$k$$, and for $$b \mid a$$, we have $$a = \ell \cdot b$$ for some integer $$\ell$$. Substituting, we get $$b = k \cdot (\ell \cdot b)$$, which means that we must have $$k \cdot \ell = 1$$, or $$k = \ell = 1$$, since $$k$$ and $$\ell$$ are both integers. Then, it must be the case that $$a = b$$ which means it is antisymmetric.

To verify that R6 is transitive, we need, for $$x, y, z \in \mathbb Z$$ that if $$x \mid y$$ and $$y \mid z$$, then $$z \mid a$$. Starting with the precondition of $$x \mid y$$, we have that $$y = k \cdot x$$ for some integer $$k$$. Similarly, $$y \mid z$$ tells us $$z = \ell \cdot y$$. Substituting, we have $$z = \ell \cdot (k \cdot x) = (\ell \cdot k) \cdot x$$. We know that $$\ell$$ and $$k$$ are both integers, so $$\ell \cdot k$$ must also be. Then, by definition, we have $$x \mid z$$, so transitivity holds

input_text: QUESTION: In the lecture notes for 14t, we prove that every graph with a certain minimum degree has a dominating set of size at most some value relative to n and the minimum degree. However, how can that be true, when technically the set of all n nodes is a valid dominating set? Furthermore, how would the probabilistic method prove that the dominating set is at most that value?
output_text:
ANSWER:

You proved that any connected graph with $$n \geq 2$$ vertices and min degree $$\delta(G) = \delta$$ contains a dominating set of size at most $$\frac{n(1 + \ln(1 + \delta))}{1 + \delta}$$. In the example you are describing, we have $$\delta = 0$$, so substituting, we get $$\frac{n(1 + \ln(1 + 0)}{1 + 0} = \frac{n(1 + \ln(1)}{1} = \frac{n(1 + 0)}{1} = n$$.

So it still works.

input_text: QUESTION:
output_text:
ANSWER:

First note that $$2^{1-\binom{k}{2}} = 2^{1 - \frac{k(k-1)}{2}}$$ just by expansion/formula. So really, all we need to show is that $$\binom{n}{k} \leq \frac{n^k}{k!}$$.

Note that $$\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} = \frac{n \cdot (n-1) \cdot ... \cdot (n-k+1)}{k!}$$.

But note that $$n \cdot (n-1) \cdot (n-2) \cdot ... \cdot (n-k+1) \leq n \cdot n \cdot n \cdot ... \cdot n$$. There are $$k$$ terms being multiplied together on the LHS, so in its entirety, it is $$\leq n^k$$. Thus, substituting back in, we have $$\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n \cdot (n-1) \cdot ... \cdot (n-k+1)}{k!} \leq \frac{n^k}{k!}$$ as desired

input_text:
QUESTION:

For the last question on ramsey numbers, can someone please explain what the 2^(- k choose 2) means? I am not understanding the math given the context of the problem. The 2 represents the number of ways to color the graph (2 colors for example) but the k choose 2 part is confusing me. Thanks!

Screenshot_2023-12-16_at_11.47.22_AM.png
output_text:
ANSWER:

It comes from the fact that we are trying to find the probability that the edges of $$E(S)$$ are monochromatic. Since $$G$$ is a complete graph, for any $$S \subseteq V$$, the induced subgraph formed by vertices of $$S$$ will also be complete. If $$|S| = k$$, then the induced subgraph has $$\binom{k}{2}$$ edges (this follows from the fact that a complete graph on $$n$$ vertices has $$\binom{n}{2}$$ edges, which is argued by saying that "every pair of vertices needs an edge between them, and there are $$\binom{n}{2}$$ distinct pairs of vertices).

Then, if there are $$\binom{k}{2}$$ edges, the probability that they are all colored BLUE would be $$\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\binom{k}{2}}$$ by independence. And similarly, the probability that they are all colored RED would also be $$\left(\frac12 \right)^{\binom{k}{2}}$$. So the probability that all edges are monochromatic is $$\left(\frac12 \right)^{\binom{k}{2}} + \left(\frac12 \right)^{\binom{k}{2}} = 2 \cdot \left(\frac12 \right)^{\binom{k}{2}} = 2 \cdot 2^{-\binom{k}{2}}$$.

The rest follows by counting the amount of $$S$$'s there are.

input_text: QUESTION: When we state that the minimum degree is at most 5, for the proof in lecture 15H Question on Coloring Planar Graphs, how can we conclude that some vertex v has deg(v) <= 5 if the max degree is not bounded? output_text: ANSWER: When we say that a graph has minimum degree of at most $$5$$, that means that if we look at all vertices, and all of their degrees, the vertex with the minimum degree has value of $$\leq 5$$. In other words, we can always find some vertex $$v$$ such that $$\deg(v)$$ is at most 5, or equivalently, $$\deg(v) \leq 5$$ for some vertex $$v$$.

input_text: QUESTION: I don't exactly understand what a Ramsey number is. If there are 2 conditions, then does that mean that there are 2 ramsey numbers for every k and l? How are the two related?
output_text: ANSWER: $$R(k, l) = n$$ means that for any graph on $$n$$ vertices, there either exists a clique of size $$k$$ or there exists an independent set of size $$l$$. That is, Ramsey numbers are defined by two parameters, but each pair of parameters yields a single value $$n$$.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Is a graph a subdivision of itself since an edge is a path?

Also, are the terms subgraph and subdivision meant to be different here? Is there a reason why?
output_text:
ANSWER:
Is a graph a subdivision of itself since an edge is a path?

Yes. 

Also, are the terms subgraph and subdivision meant to be different here? Is there a reason why?

There is a difference between subdivision and subgraph. A subdivision is obtained by taking an edge, and introducing vertices along that edge -- we are dividing an edge into a bunch of smaller edges. A subgraph does not introduce anything new. It is simply a subset of vertices and edges of the original graph

input_text: QUESTION: I solved this question doing TT instead of MT to understand the process better. I got 26 instead of 26^2, and I semi-understand the intuition. I was wondering if you could explain why it makes sense for this solution to be different than MT. Because, if the question was asking the expectation of dishes you would need to get at least 1 TT it is the same solution as MT. However, the question in 12H yields different solutions.
output_text:
ANSWER:

Here is some intuition: 

When looking at MT, suppose you have hit an M, and are looking at the next letter that follows. There are 3 cases to consider:

  • The next letter is a T, in which case you are done.
  • The next letter is an M, in which case, not all hope is lost, as you can still obtain a T immediately next.
  • The next letter is something else, in which case, you must "restart" your count.

When looking at TT, there are only 2 cases to consider if you have hit a T.

  • The next letter is a T, in which case you are done. 
  • The next letter is anything else, in which case, you must "restart" your count.

Since there is a significant difference in the cases, we would expect the values to not be identical.

input_text: QUESTION: The answer key on Canvas shows a different method, but the rubric on Gradescope says it's possible to do it with Hall's theorem. I tried this approach and was confused about proving that each member in X must have at least k+1 neighbors and the subsequent step which is to apply the Hall's condition.
output_text: ANSWER: Since each vertex has degree $$ \geq 2k$$, consider an arbitrary vertex $$x \in X$$ where $$X$$ is an arbitrary subset of size $$|X| = k$$. Then, $$x$$ has at most $$k-1$$ neighbors in $$X$$, and thus at least $$2k - (k-1) = k+1$$ neighbors in $$V \setminus X$$.

input_text: QUESTION: Could someone help explain how we got the first few steps in this calculation?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Yep. First line is an expansion using the conditional expectation formula (which I think we proved in lecture). From line 1 to line 2, we are applying memoryless. So the first term has a $$\Pr[Y = 1]$$ in it. This occurs with probability $$p$$, because it denotes the probability that we "succeed" on the first trial. Then, take a look at $$\mathbb{E}[X^2|Y = 1]$$. This reads as "the expected value of $$X^2$$ given that $$Y = 1$$", or, equivalently, but less mathematically, "the expected value of the "number of trials until our first success" squared, given that the first trial was a success. Well, if the first trial was a success ($$Y = 1$$), then it must be that the total number of trials until the first success is $$1$$, so we have $$X = 1 \implies X^2 = 1$$. Thus, $$\mathbb{E}[X^2|Y = 1] = 1$$. So that entire first term is $$p \cdot 1 = p$$.

The second term follows similarly, however the tricky part is $$\mathbb{E}[X^2 |Y = 0]$$. Given that $$Y = 0$$, we can't conclude that $$X = 1$$ as we did before, but we can say that "we failed on the first trial, but we still need to succeed". After the first trial, the number of trials in expectation to succeed is $$\mathbb{E}[X]$$. Therefore, given $$Y = 0$$, it would be that $$\mathbb{E}[X^2 | Y = 1] = (\mathbb{E}[X] + 1)^2$$.

This is a very "intuitive" explanation and is much better proven using the actual memoryless property, which is something I encourage you to do!

The remaining lines are just algebra

input_text: QUESTION: Does an equivalence relation constructed from two equivalence classes as done in Lecture 13t have to be exhaustive? aka do i have to include all possible ordered pairs of the relation or can I exclude some as long as reflexity, symmetry, and transitivity hold?
output_text: ANSWER: In the case of the example in 13T, the answer provided is the only correct answer. You have to be really careful when coming up with the elements of the relation because not only must you ensure that reflexivity, transitivity, and symmetry hold, but you must also ensure that the equivalence classes are valid. That is, if I chose to exclude, say, $$(1, 3)$$ from $$R$$, then that would be an invalid answer, because $$1$$ and $$3$$ would no longer be in the same equivalence class.

input_text: QUESTION: On the review session, for a r.v. X,  there exists an object for which X \geq E[X] and there exists an object for which X \leq E[X]. Is this because there's an equal sign? I understand the X \geq E[X] part, but I don't understand the X \leq E[X] part.
output_text: ANSWER: There's a pretty decent explanation of this at the ~13:50 minute mark of the recording. But yes, it is important to conclude that $$\exists X$$ such that $$X \leq \mathbb{E}[X]$$ instead of $$X < \mathbb{E}[X]$$. That is, a strict inequality would be an incorrect conclusion. This can be argued by contradiction where you assume that all $$X > \mathbb{E}[X]$$, and then you contradict that the actual value that $$\mathbb{E}[X]$$ is cannot be.

input_text: QUESTION: For 2b, the equivalence classes are the set of red vertices and the set of blue vertices. The expected number of red vertices is n/3, and the expected number of blue vertices is 2n/3. Then, why isn't |R| = (n/3)^2 + (2n/3)^2 = 5n^2/9?
output_text:
ANSWER:

This is a really good question!

If $$X$$ is a random variable denoting the number of red vertices, and $$Y$$ is a random variable denoting the number of blue vertices, then, as you have implicitly noted, $$|R| = X \cdot X + Y \cdot Y$$.

So, $$\mathbb{E}[|R|] = \mathbb{E}[X \cdot X + Y \cdot Y] = \mathbb{E}[X^2] + \mathbb{Y^2}$$.

But it is important to note that it is not always true that $$\mathbb{E}[X^2] = \mathbb{E}[X]^2$$. The equation you have provided is assuming that $$\mathbb{E}[X^2] = \mathbb{E}[X]^2 = (n/3)^2$$, which is incorrect

input_text:
QUESTION:

How do we prove that a number is an integer?
output_text:
ANSWER:

If you're just looking at a number, say 7, you can just say that it is an integer. But if it is a more abstract quantity (such as the product/sum of other numbers/variables), then some sort of justification based on the closure of integers would suffice.

For example, suppose I want to show that $$k = 2x + y$$ is an integer. And suppose we know that $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers, then you could just say that $$k$$ is an integer because $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers and the integer set is closed under addition and multiplication.

ANSWER:

In short, a closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. Some examples would be $$1, x^2 + 1$$ or $$2n$$.

Examples of expressions that are not closed form usually involve summations with non-constant bounds such as $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$. We'll be posting a more in-depth description of what closed form is on piazza very soon. 

Update: @138

input_text:
QUESTION:

Hi!


I just got a bit confuse on the way that the proof on 2.sp2 was done for ((A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A ). I understood all the mathematical computations on why x (an arbitrary element) belongs to A, but got stuck on the reasoning why by given that x ∈ A and x ∈ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B),  (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A  must be true. Why couldn't it be the other way around where A ⊆ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ? 

Thanks in advance!
output_text:
ANSWER:

Well that conclusion is being made because we are under the case of showing that $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$. Remember, to show equality, we show inclusion in both directions. So focusing on the direction $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$, we would want to show that for any element that appears in the left hand side, it must also appear in the right hand side. 2.sp2 argues that for any element $$x \in (A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$, we have $$x \in A$$, so we have that any element in the left hand side also appears in the right hand side (since x was arbitrary), and by definition of subset, we conclude that the left hand side is a subset of the right hand side. 

We then go on to show the inclusion in the other direction. And to show that, we would go about taking an arbitrary element of $$A$$ and show that it appears in $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$.

I think the key thing to note is the definition of subset. We have $$A \subset B$$ if and only if for every element $$a \in A$$, we also have $$a \in B$$. That's what we are doing in the set proofs; we consider an element $$a \in A$$ and then show that it must be that $$a \in B$$ and then conclude that $$A \subseteq B$$

QUESTION:

Which sets are they referring to when they say the sets are pairwise disjoint? I thought if the sets were pairwise disjoint they could not have any elements in common.
output_text:
ANSWER:

Each $$S_i$$ is a set of sets, and it is true that the $$S_i$$'s are pairwise disjoint with respect to one another.

This is because, consider any two of these sets $$S_i$$ and $$S_j$$, for an arbitrary $$x \in S_i$$, we have $$|x| = i$$. However, we know that for any $$y \in S_j$$ we have $$|y| = j$$. So it always holds that $$x \notin S_j$$. This means that $$S_i \cap S_j = \emptyset$$ and thus are pairwise disjoint.

input_text: QUESTION:
output_text:
ANSWER:

In one sentence: Stars and bars is an application of simple combinations.

For more detail, with simple combinations, such as $$\binom{n}{r}$$, we are simply considering a set of $$n$$ distinct items and determining how many ways can we choose $$r$$ of these items. Equivalently, this counts the number of subsets of size $$r$$ from our original set.

Stars and bars can be thought of as a two step procedure. We see a direct correlation between distributing indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers with an arrangement of stars and bars. So to count the number of ways to distribute, we count the number of arrangements of stars and bars. Suppose we have $$n$$ stars and $$r-1$$ bars, then our procedure would begin by choosing $$n$$ locations to put the stars. Since the remaining open slots must be filled with bars, they can only be filled in one way. So by MR, you get the familiar equation for stars and bars which is $$\binom{n + r - 1}{n}$$, or equivalently, $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

I don't really understand what example 1,2  means - is there a more concrete explanation/example for this? Also, what is g(f) and h(f) for the question below?
output_text:
ANSWER:

g and h are examples of functions that have the domain $$B^A$$ and codomain $$2^C$$. So the domain of g and h are functions and the codomain of g and h are subsets of [1..n].

A good question is what is the size of the domain? And what is the size of the codomain? 

The domain has size $$n^n$$ and the codomain has size $$2^n$$. 

To understand the function $$g$$, consider an arbitrary function $$\phi: [1..n] \rightarrow [1..n]$$. Note that $$\phi \in [1..n]^{[1..n]}$$, so it is in the domain. Note that $$\phi$$ takes as input $$x \in [1..n]$$ and outputs some $$y \in [1..n]$$. That is, $$\phi(x) = y$$ where $$x, y \in [1..n]$$.

When evaluating $$g(\phi)$$, we note that the mapping is defined by $$\{x | f(x) = 1\}$$ where $$x \in [1..n]$$. Therefore, the mapping is looking at all elements of $$[1..n]$$ such that when $$\phi$$ acts on that element, the output is $$1$$. These elements form a subset of $$[1..n]$$. How exciting! Let's call this subset $$A$$. That is, we have $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ and $$\forall a \in A$$, we have $$\phi(a) = 1$$. 

Then, $$g(\phi) = A$$.

For function $$h$$, we do something similar, but now $$h$$ maps $$\phi$$ to its range (which is also a subset of $$[1..n]$$). 

For the last part of the question, we are given $$f$$ as the identity function. This means, $$\forall x \in [1..n]$$ we have $$f(x) = x$$. We want to compute $$g(f)$$. This is equivalent to asking: "What is the set $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ such that $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$f(a) = 1$$?". Well, if $$f$$ is the identity, then it must be that $$A = \{1\}$$. Therefore, $$g(f) = \{1\}$$.

For $$h(f)$$ we ask ourselves, "if $$f$$ is the identity function, what is $$Ran(f)$$?". Well, this is just $$[1..n]$$. So, we have $$h(f) = [1..n]$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

Screen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM

What is the set J? Is this the set that we're finding the intersections for when we're counting using PIE? Also, can you explain the RHS - why are we placing elements in the other n-k positions?
output_text:
ANSWER:

J is just an arbitrary subset of $$[1..n]$$. It basically narrows down which values we are focusing on (of whether or not they are in the right position) in the permutation. 

For the RHS, recall that elements of $$\bigcap_{j \in J} B_j$$ will be those permutations such that the elements of $$j$$ are in the right position. So we can compute the cardinality of this via a procedure where in the first step, we fix the elements of $$J$$ in their correct position (of which there are $$k$$ elements) and then we permute the remaining elements. The first step occurs in just 1 way, and the second step occurs in $$(n-k)!$$ ways.

input_text:
QUESTION:

I was doing some practice questions I found online and one was about proving that some set operations equaled the empty set.

In this class, we learned double inclusion to prove equality between two sets, but I figure you can't do that for empty sets because there is no abp element of an empty set.

So how would we approach proving this rigorously? Just show that the operations limit the scope of the set to nothing?
output_text:
ANSWER:

I suppose you could do the normal double inclusion method. Suppose you were asked to prove $$LHS = \emptyset$$. You could go about showing $$LHS \subseteq \emptyset$$ by considering an arbitrary element of the LHS and reach some sort of verdict based on that. And then when you show $$\emptyset \subseteq LHS$$, you would not have to consider an arbitrary element, because $$\emptyset \subseteq A$$ for any set $$A$$. So this side would just follow as fact.

QUESTION:

What's our definition of real numbers, natural numbers, and integers?
output_text:
ANSWER:

$$\mathbb{N} = \{0, 1, 2, 3, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers starting from 0.

$$\mathbb{Z} = \{... -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers.

$$\mathbb{R}$$ contains all positive or negative whole numbers, fractions or decimals. 

This yields the following relationships: $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$$, $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$, $$\mathbb{Z} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$

QUESTION:

Are these two different definitions? If so, can you explain the difference?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Two sets are said to be disjoint if they share no elements in common. That is, $$A$$ and $$B$$ are disjoint when $$A \cap B = \emptyset$$. The term "pairwise disjoint" has a definition that builds off the definition of "disjoint". We say a collection of sets $$A_1, A_2, ..., A_n$$ are pairwise disjoint when $$\forall i, j$$, we have $$A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset$$.

QUESTION:

For Q4, I have a solution that works as follows (very brief explanation):

Choose arbitrary TA t1 out of the n possible TAs. Denote set W to be all the TA's t1 directly wins over and set L to be all the TA's t1 directly loses to. Then 2 cases:

Case 1: every element in L lost to at least 1 element in W so therefore TA t1 is supreme since either directly or indirectly beat everyone.  Done!

Case 2: there exists some TA t2 in the set L that beats every TA in the set W. From here we can restart the process considering TA t2 to be the new potential supreme TA, the set W to be the same set as before + t1 + any number of elements in the set L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |W| can increase from before as it only gains new elements and can not lose element). The set L will be the same as before but will lose t2 and any elements that were initially in L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |L| decreases because L can only lose elements not gain any. 

From there repeat the two cases with TA t2 as the new potential supreme TA with the new set W and the new set L. Since W can only grow, and L can only lose elements then we can continue the process until Case 1 reached or |L| becomes 0 and therefore case 1 reached. 

So sorry for the long explanation but hope that made sense. My question is can I use this form of proof here? Am I allowed to simply say continue the process until case 1 is reached (therefore defining a supreme TA) or |L| = 0 which also defines a supreme TA?

ANSWER:

we cannot comment on the correctness of a proof

input_text:
QUESTION:

this is for personal understanding only and in no means related to required material, but can expectation be thought of as a linear operator? More exactly, $$\hat{E}:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, $$ $$\hat{E}(X) = \vec{x} \cdot \vec{p}$$, where $$p_i = Pr[X=x_i]$$ and $$x_i \in Val(X)$$
output_text:
ANSWER:

sort of. We can see that the canonical equation for expectation of $$\mathbb E[X] = \sum_{x \in Val(x)} x \cdot \Pr[X = x]$$ is indeed a linear function. 

I wouldn't say that the domain of your provided $$\hat{E}$$ is $$\mathbb R$$ because we define a random variable to be a function. 

Otherwise, sure. You've basically described expectation as a dot product between two vectors, which is exactly what a summation of the product of two entities is.

input_text: QUESTION: Why are we solving for when we are returning the ith pair of sock? How does this lead us to find the expected pair of socks
output_text:
ANSWER:

The total amount of socks being returned can be thought of as a sum of a bunch of $$1$$'s and $$0$$'s, where a 1 indicates if the sock has been returned and a 0 otherwise. For example, suppose we put in 3 pairs of socks (we'll label these pairs A, B, and C) and only received 2 back. And further, suppose that we didn't receive pair B back. Then, it is true that we received 1 + 0 + 1 = 2 pairs back (1 for A and 1 for C). This is essentially what indicators are. So if we were to define an indicator for each pair of socks, and sum them all together, we would get the total amount of pairs returned.

Thus, if $$S = I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n$$, then $$\mathbb{E}[S] = \mathbb{E}[I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n]$$. And by using Linearity of Expectation, we have this being equal to $$\mathbb{E}[I_1] + \mathbb{E}[I_2] + ... + \mathbb{E}[I_n] = \sum_{i=1}^n \mathbb{E}[I_i]$$.

So our problem has been reduced to finding the expected value of an indicator, where the indicator is whether or not the $$i$$th pair is returned. By finding this value, we can easily obtain $$\mathbb{E}[S]$$ using the math above.

This means that for each element of your outcome space, the random variable assigns it some real number value via some function you have defined. It is possible for there to be an $$\omega \in \Omega$$ such that $$\Pr[\omega] = 0$$, but since $$\omega \in \Omega$$, $$X(\omega)$$ must have some real value assigned to it (since $$\Omega$$ is the domain of $$X$$).

QUESTION:

For example, I may have a probability space $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ where I'm rolling 2023 dice. But let's say I want to focus on the first 10 dice. Can I define $$(\omega, Pr)$$ within $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ to "zoom in"? Or should I say these are two separate probability spaces?
output_text:
ANSWER:

the short answer is "probably". The long answer would require a lot more conversation about what you are intending to do by "focusing" on the first 10 dice rolls. 

In general, I would try to avoid a "sub-probability space" and rather just define an event. Most ideas I can think of that involve "focusing on the first 10 dice" can be solved by just defining an event and giving its corresponding probability.

For example, I could define $$E$$ to be the event that the first 10 dice rolls are all even numbers. And this would be a perfectly fine event definition since $$E \subseteq \Omega$$. And then we could go about computing $$Pr[E]$$ in whichever way fancies us.

ADDENDUM: In general when we "restrict" the sample space like this we need to show that the new probability problem is equivalent to the old problem.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Is this a wrong method? Also, if it is not explicitly stated, can we still write answers in open form? How would we write the below answer in closed form? Thank you
output_text:
ANSWER:

Yes this is a valid solution. You can simplify this by first noting, from Pascal's triangle, that:

$$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + ... + \binom{2n}{2n} = 2^{2n}$$.

Then, we see that $$\binom{2n}{0} = \binom{2n}{2n}$$, $$\binom{2n}{1} = \binom{2n}{2n-1}$$, etc. so the above simplifies to:

$$(\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{2n}) + (\binom{2n}{1} + \binom{2n}{2n-1}) + ... + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$

$$2 \cdot \binom{2n}{0} + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{1} + ... + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{n-1} + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$

$$2 \cdot \left( \binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} \right) = 2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}$$.

And thus, $$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}$$.

So then your final answer would become $$\frac{\frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}}{2^{2n}} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2^{2n+1}}$$ which is the correct answer.

Your answers should always be in closed form unless we explicitly mention that open form solutions are allowed.

input_text:
QUESTION:

So sorry, but I think that I am having trouble with understanding Q1's answer/logic. I know that we are pigeonholing on the values of the codomain, but don't see how this guarantees f(1) = g(1)? Is the pigeonhole H where all functions in this hole have all their domain values are mapped to the codomain value 1 (or 2 or 3 WLOG)? Or would someone mind pointing me to the question that I remember we did that was similar to this in either one of the lectures or extra practice problems, if they can remember it?
output_text:
ANSWER:

No need to apologize -- I agree that the wording of Q1 is a bit odd. 

The argument here is that we have $$3^3 = 27$$ possible functions, and we will assign them to holes based on where they "send" the value 1. That is, we will have holes labeled 0, 1, and 2 (for the three possible values of the codomain, and for a function $$f$$ (which is a pigeon), it will be placed in the hole labeled $$f(1)$$.

By PHP, you we can conclude that there exists a hole with at least $$\lceil \frac{27}{3} \rceil = 9$$ pigeons (functions) in it. But we notice that for two functions $$f$$ and $$g$$ to be in the same hole, it must be the case that $$f(1) = g(1)$$. In other words, suppose we have two functions $$f$$ and $$g$$ that both landed in hole (WLOG) 0. Then, by construction, it MUST be that we had $$f(1) = 0$$ and $$g(1) = 0$$, so we can say that $$f(1) = g(1)$$.

Since our hole has $$9$$ pigeons, it must be the case that the output of all of them on input $$1$$ is equal. So we take any $$9$$ of the pigeons/functions that landed in this hole.

QUESTION:

Based on the given recurrence relation and intuition (one cut would split the pizza into 2 pieces), I'm confused about why C(1) is 1 in the recursion tree? Am I missing something?
output_text:
ANSWER:

The tree isn't saying that $$C(1) = 1$$, but rather that $$C(1)$$ will "contribute" or "add" 1 when we encounter it. In other words, it adds 1 to the value of the sum of the previous terms. This value comes from the recurrence relation being $$C(n) = C(n-1) + {\color{red} n}$$ where the $${\color{red} n}$$ is the "addition" part. This is also why the tree is called a "tree of additions".

$$\{\omega_1, \omega_3\}$$ is defined to be equivalent to $$E$$, which is an event. Recall that an event is defined to be a subset of the outcome space. In words, we would say that "E is the event that one of $$\omega_1$$ or $$\omega_3$$ occurs". 

Since an event $$E \subseteq \Omega$$ (that is, $$E$$ is a subset), we can perform set operations on it.

So $$E \cap F$$ is the intersection of events $$E$$ and $$F$$, which is the outcomes that are described by both $$E$$ and $$F$$.

input_text:
QUESTION:

How is it that A is a subset of both B and C when B and C are independent - and from there, since B and C are independent, how can the intersection of A B and C be 1 (I thought it would be 0)?
output_text:
ANSWER:

In general, events $$B$$ and $$C$$ are independent if $$\Pr[B \cap C] = \Pr[B] \cdot \Pr[C]$$. This does not mean that $$B \cap C = \emptyset$$ or $$\Pr[B \cap C] = 0$$. These could occur, but do not have to. 

This implies that we may have $$B \cap C \neq \emptyset$$, which means we can have a non-empty $$A \subseteq B$$ and $$A \subseteq C$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

Why do we need base cases for both n=0 and n
output_text:
ANSWER:

If we only showed $$n = 0$$, then in our IH, the value of $$k$$ would be bounded as $$k \geq 0$$. So in the induction step, we would consider $$k + 1$$, which could take on the value of $$1$$ (when $$k = 0$$). Then, we would not be able to say that $$P(k-1)$$ holds by our IH, and we would thus be stuck.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Why exactly can we conclude that Pr[X <= (a+b)/2] = Pr[X=a] when a < (a+b)/2?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Because $$\mathrm{Val}(X) = \{a, b\}$$, which means that for any $$\alpha \neq a, b$$, we would have $$\Pr[X = \alpha] = 0$$. Therefore, to calculate $$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}]$$, we can take the following sum:

$$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}] = \sum_{\alpha \leq \frac{a+b}{2}} \Pr[X = \alpha]$$. But all of these probabilities will be $$0$$ except when $$\alpha = a$$. So the sum reduces to $$\Pr[X = a]$$.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Since in induction we use p(k) to derive p(k+1), our assumption contains some relation with k and k+1 (or more). Then is it almost always the case that our base case would need to have more than just P(0)? Also, is it wrong if we just write more than one base case all the time?
output_text:
ANSWER:

No. In ordinary induction, we almost always need only one base case. This is because we only "rely" on one prior term. It is not wrong to have more than one base case, but from a convention/proof writing standpoint, it is better to have just one base case than multiple unnecessary base cases.

output_text:
ANSWER:

This is because we want to prove it for all $$n \geq 1$$ and the recurrence is defined for all $$n \geq 1$$. In other recurrence relations, there are usually some base cases defined outside of the recurrence relation, and we would need multiple base cases in induction so that in the induction step, we are working with values of $$k+1$$ that we can use the recurrence relation on.

input_text:
QUESTION:

Hi! I was just wondering how we got from n! - | B1 u B2 ... u Bn | to the final equation of the form n! (1 - 1/1! ... + (-1)^n/n!). Thank you so much!!
output_text:
ANSWER:

We are just doing PIE to get the parenthetical part. We have:

$$|B_1 \cup ... \cup B_n| = \sum_i |B_i| - \sum_{i, j} |B_i \cap B_j| + \sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| - \ldots + \sum_{1..n} |B_1 \cap B_2 \cap ... \cap B_n|$$

Consider, for example, the third summation of $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k|$$. In words, for a single $$i, j, k$$, we have that $$B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k$$ being the permutations in which $$h_i$$ does appear in position $$i$$, $$h_j$$ does appear in position $$j$$, and $$h_k$$ does appear in position $$k$$.

To find this cardinality, we do a simple counting procedure:

Step 1: Place $$h_i, h_j, h_k$$ in positions $$i, j, k$$ respectively (1 way)

Step 2: Arrange the remaining elements ($$(n-3)!$$ ways)

So for a single $$i, j, k$$, we have $$|B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = (n-3)!$$. For the summation term , we have $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = \sum_{i, j, k} (n-3)!$$. The question is, how many $$i, j, k$$ triples are there? Well, there are $$\binom{n}{3} = \frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!}$$.

So this summation term reduces to $$\frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!} \cdot (n-3)! = \frac{n!}{3!}$$.

You can do a similar thing for all of the other summations, plug it back into the PIE equation, and factor out an $$n!$$, and you will get the desired expression.

input_text:
QUESTION:

I am confused because for (a) - this is not a conditional probability? How do you define "all the other cards you drew are aces, twos, threes, or fours" as a separate event from "event that you draw 4 of spades"?
output_text:
ANSWER:

You could solve this using conditional probability.

Let A be the event that the 12 other cards in your hand are Ace, 2, 3, 4. Let B be the event that you drew the 4 of spades.

Then, $$\Pr[A | B] = \frac{\Pr[A \cap B]}{\Pr[B]} = \frac{\frac{|A \cap B|}{|\Omega|}}{\frac{|B|}{|\Omega|}} = \frac{|A \cap B|}{|B|}$$.

To calculate $$|A \cap B|$$, we need to find the number of hands that have the 4 of spades and all the remaining cards are Aces, 2, 3, 4. Consider the counting procedure:

Step 1: Include the 4 of spades in your hand.

Step 2: Out of all remaining possible Aces, 2's, 3's and 4's, choose 12 cards to include in your hand.

Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2 can be performed in $$\binom{15}{12}$$ ways. So by MR, $$|A \cap B| = \binom{15}{12}$$.

To calculate $$|B|$$, we need the number of hands that have the 4 of spades.

Step 1: Include the 4 of spades.

Step 2: Choose 12 remaining cards.

Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2, since there are 51 cards left to choose from, can be performed in $$\binom{51}{12}$$ ways.

Substitute, and we get the same answer.

input_text:
QUESTION:

The question in the video is:

How many cycles of length 4 are there in $$~K_4$$?

How is the correct answer of 15 obtained?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Let $$K_5 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.

Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.

Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. 

Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:

1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$

2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$

3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.

By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$

QUESTION:

Are we allowed to use both constructive and non-constructive proof for existence?

Existence proofs: To prove a statement of the form ∃x ∈ S,P(x), we give either a constructive or a non-contructive proof. In a constructive proof, one proves the statement by exhibiting a specific x ∈ S such that P(x) is true. In a non-constructive proof, one proves the statement using an indirect proof such as a proof by contradiction. Thus, one might prove that the negation ∀x ∈ S,∼ P(x) is false by deriving a contradiction.
output_text: ANSWER: Yes -Ishaan

input_text: QUESTION: for the induction step, if we want to show that a claim holds for a full binary tree of height k+1, do we need to start with the tree of height k+1, or can we start with a height of k (and then add vertices to get to a height k+1)?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Usually in graph induction, you should start with the $$k+1$$ case, reduce it down to the $$k$$ case, and then build back up to the $$k+1$$ case.

This is because when starting from $$k$$ and going to $$k+1$$ directly, we may not consider every single graph that has $$k+1$$ things.

input_text: QUESTION: how do we know whether we should induct on vertices or edges?
output_text:
ANSWER:

What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.

For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)

What's nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don't have to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.

input_text: QUESTION: In the first part of the proof, when we delete at least 2 nodes, why don't we consider the case of bringing these nodes back? same for the second part, when we add, why we don't remove it after it?
output_text:
ANSWER:

We can equivalently re-write the solution as follows:

"The resulting tree, call it $$T'$$ has height $$k$$. By the IH, $$T'$$ has $$\geq 2k + 1$$ nodes. Since we removed $$\geq 2$$ nodes, our original tree $$T$$ by re-introducing the nodes we removed, has $$\geq (2k + 1) + 2 = 2(k+1) + 1$$ nodes."

For the second part of the proof, we are starting from the $$k$$ case and building up to the $$k+1$$ case, so there is no need to remove the nodes.

If $$P_4$$ is the graph $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)\}$$, then the complement is the graph with vertex set $$V' = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and edges $$E' = \{(v_1, v_3), (v_1, v_4), (v_2, v_4)\}$$.

The bijection $$\phi: V \mapsto V'$$ is defined by $$\phi(v_1) = v_2$$, $$\phi(v_2) = v_4$$, $$\phi(v_3) = v_1$$ and $$\phi(v_4) = v_3$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

In a tree $$G=(V,E)$$ (undirected), adding one more edge will result in a cycle, by the minimally acyclic property (and hopefully we don't have to prove this on the final...?). Following this logic, do we know that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1? If so, do we have to prove it, and how might we approach this proof?

Related, if a connected undirected graph with $$n$$ vertices has exactly $$k$$ cycles, does such a graph have exactly $$k$$ extra edges compared to its spanning tree?

This question is inspired by Final Review Q11 for reference
output_text:
ANSWER:

It is NOT true that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1. Take, for example, $$G = (V, E)$$ with $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)$$. This graph is a tree with zero cycles. Adding the edge $$(v_4, v_1)$$ creates a single cycle. However, if we were to add another edge (while still including $$(v_4, v_1)$$), say $$(v_1, v_3)$$, then the resulting graph has $$3$$ cycles.

It follows that the answer to your "related" question is no.

input_text:
QUESTION:

In the proof on the solutions, it says:

\\

With this we can say that the graph must
have an even number of vertices because there are only odd degree vertices.
\\
What is the broader logic behind this?
output_text: ANSWER: $$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2|E|$$. This tells us that the sum of the degrees of the vertices must be an even number. If there were an odd number of vertices, then $$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v)$$ would be odd (the sum of and odd amount of odd numbers is odd), but that's a contradiction.

input_text:
QUESTION:

For arbitrary n ≥ 2, give an example of a set X and a function g : X → [1..n] that is not

injective and moreover | Ran(g)| = n − 1.

The answer is

DefineX=[1..n]andforeach1 ≤ k ≤ n define

g(k) =

k if 1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1 n−1 if k=n.

--

Are we able to say that the range of the answer is n - 1 because the nth term is not getting mapped to. Does this mean that range is how many values in the codomain are getting mapped to? Not just how many values are in the codomain? Thanks!
output_text: ANSWER: The range is the set of values in the codomain that are being mapped to. That is, for a function $$g: X \mapsto Y$$, we have $$y \in Ran(g)$$ if $$\exists x \in X$$ such that $$g(x) = y$$. And we see that $$Ran(g) \subseteq Y$$.

QUESTION:

In homework10 we proved that the chromatic number $$\chi(G)$$ is greater or equal to the size of the largest clique in $$G$$, $$\kappa (G)$$. The example we used to disprove $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ for all $$G$$ was the case of any odd cycle in $$G$$.

Therefore, would any graph $$G$$ that doesn't contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?

Or, in other words, would $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ hold for any $$\chi(G) \geq 3$$?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Would any graph $$G$$ that doesn't contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?

We have shown that a graph without an odd cycle is bipartite. So it would remain to show that a graph with no odd cycles would have max clique size of $$2$$. It's pretty easy to show why this is true via contradiction (suppose you had a clique of size 3 or larger...)

input_text: QUESTION: If we want to distribute n stars to r people but we want all of them to have at least 1 star and exactly 3 of them to have at least 2 stars, how do we solve the problem? Also, what would happen if it was at least 3 people instead of exactly 3?
output_text:
ANSWER:

If there are $$n$$ people, and exactly 3 of them must have at least 2 star and the remaining $$n-3$$ people must have at least one star, then it must be the case that the $$n-3$$ people all have exactly one star. So give those people all one star, then do stars & bars with the remaining stars amongst the 3 people left. 

For the second question, you could probably do some complementary counting PIE type stuff.

input_text:
QUESTION:

hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set 'belongs to' another set and the set is a 'subset' of another set

so the 'belongs to' for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,

while for the 'subset' part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Your definition for "belongs to" is correct.

One way of thinking about "subset" is "A is a subset of B if every element of A is also an element of B". So for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$, then $$A \subseteq B$$, because every element of A is also an element of B. But if $$A = \{1, 4\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$ then $$A \nsubseteq B$$

input_text:
QUESTION:

In the Lecture example: "How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?" 

why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.

Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What's the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? 

Is it that in a question in which there are multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.
output_text:
ANSWER:

Note that only Attempt 3 shows a correct solution for the "odd numbers" question. In that attempt, we can see that we will not select the number zero in steps 1 and 2. Only the second digit and the third digit can be zeroes, which is why they are placed last in our ordering of steps. But these steps also acknowledge the fact that, for example, the second digit cannot be the same as the first or fourth digit (whose digits have already been chosen), which is why there are 10 - 2 = 8 ways to perform step 3. And similar logic holds for step 4.

I'm not sure I completely understand your second question, but I'll try my best to give some information that may clear things up. Steps within your process that you develop for counting CAN depend on each other, but we can only perform MR when each step has a CONSTANT number of ways of being performed. For example, in attempt 1 of the "secretary" question, the third step can be performed in 2 ways if, for example, Bob is President and Ann is Treasurer, 1 way if, for example, Bob is president and Clyde is secretary, or 0 ways if, for example, Clyde is president and Dan is secretary. Since this is NOT a constant value, the MR can't really be used.

Whereas, in attempt 2, since we chose the secretary first, the remaining two steps always have the same constant number of people to choose from.

For your last question, no. There can be many ways of ordering the steps. You just need to be sure that the ordering of the steps meets the above rule of that constant value for each step.

hope that made a bit of sense!

As an example, suppose three of the cars are called $$A$$, $$B$$ and $$C$$ (distinguishable), and suppose the three interests are called $$x$$, $$y$$, and $$z$$.

Then one possible distribution of these cars would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$B$$ to $$y$$ and $$C$$ to $$z$$. But clearly, there are many more ways to distribute the cars.

If, however, the cars were indistinguishable, then we could all give them the same name of $$A$$. And the only way to distribute the cars now would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$A$$ to $$y$$ and $$A$$ to $$z$$. 

As a reminder, ALL eight cars must be distributed amongst his interests.

input_text: QUESTION: How does this word influence how we do counting?
output_text:
ANSWER:

Let's consider two similar questions:

Question 1: How many ways are there to give two distinguishable watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.

Solution: Let $$A$$ be the first watch and $$B$$ be the second watch. Let $$X$$ be the first person and let $$Y$$ be the second person. Then we have two distributions: $$((A, X), (B, Y))$$ and $$((A, Y), (B, X)$$. 

Question 2: How many ways are there to give two indistinguishable watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.

Solution: Now, we cannot call our watches $$A$$ and $$B$$ because they are indistinguishable. Instead, we will call them both $$A$$. If our people are $$X$$ and $$Y$$, then we only have one distribution: $$((A, X), (A, Y))$$. 

In a sense, "distinguishable" allows for more variety in our cases/distributions.

QUESTION:

Let's say the claim is the sum is even. If I want to prove the claim by contradiction, we assume that the sum is odd. If my contradiction is that I showed that the sum will be even (contradicting the assumption), is this considered proof by contradiction? Or is this redundant/unnecessary because I am simply proving that the sum is even directly? 

Basically, for a specific problem, I just think it's easier and clearer to understand if I prove a claim by initially assuming the opposite and thus everything that assumption implies. Then with those implications and the rest of the context of the problem show that the original claim is true. 

Hopefully, my question is clear (I tried my best haha) and I can get some guidance!
output_text:
ANSWER:

This really depends on the proof. Most of the times when doing contradiction, we end up contradicting something true that was given in the problem, though in some instances, you may end up contradicting what you assumed.

If you find yourself often proving the opposite of what you assumed, then it may be best to just stick with a direct proof.

QUESTION:

What is the different between saying "without loss of generality" and "arbitrary but particular"? When would we use each?
output_text:
ANSWER:

"Without loss of generality" is commonly used when making a claim for some variables. For example, I would say something like "suppose $$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$$, and without loss of generality, let $$a < b$$". And then I would do whatever math needed. In the instance that $$b < a$$, I wouldn't have to do any math because the "symmetric" argument is covered with "Without Loss of Generality". That is to say, we can't just be throwing around WLOG whenever we want. We should only use it when the argument truly is symmetric.

"Arbitrary but Particular" is usually used when describing an element of a set. We use this to indicate that there is "nothing special" about the element, and the argument for that element will hold for all elements of the set.
